awd_abstract_narration:
GameSec is a research conference focused on analytical models based on information, communication, optimization, decision, control and game theories that are applied to diverse security topics. At the same time, the connection between theoretical models and real world security problems are emphasized to establish the important feedback loop between theory and practice. The conference helps to promote a "science of security" with a theoretical foundation that helps us understand security risk in a principled way.

This grant provides travel support to allow more students to attend GameSec 2013. Preferences for travel support are based on the credentials of the students, with a focus on attracting women and underrepresented minority students to support their participation in this event.

GameSec 2013 Student Travel Support Request

Donggang Liu and Matthew Wright, University of Texas at Arlington

Project Outcomes Report

The Conference on Decision and Game Theory for Security (GameSec), established in 2010, aims to bring together researchers who aim to establish a theoretical foundation for making resource allocation decisions that balance available capabilities and perceived security risks in a principled manner. The conference helps to promote a “science of security” with a theoretical foundation that helps us understand security risk in a principled way. The 2013 edition of GameSec was held in Fort Worth, Texas on November 11-12.

This conference offered a valuable opportunity for researchers to share their results and learn about the state of the art in the application of decision and game theory in security. It also offered PhD and MS research students a unique platform to learn the recent advance in this area and encourage them to take initiatives in research and produce more results. This project made $5,000 in travel funding available to nine highly qualified graduate students with research interests in security and applied game theory and decision science so that they could take advantage of this opportunity.

This student funding opportunity was widely promoted on the GameSec website and by mailing lists that reach the top US groups working in security and related research areas. The nine students selected included students from various institutions ranging from the Catholic University of America in Washington, DC, to the University of Arizona. The students, eight of whom were PhD students, had published papers in a wide range of areas, including cognitive radio networks, participatory sensing, green computing, and anonymous communications – all of which might benefit from more focus on security and from the application of game theory and decision science.

Participation in conferences such as GameSec is an extremely important part of the graduate school experience, providing the opportunity to interact with peers and more senior researchers, thus having the opportunity to be exposed to leading edge work in security and privacy. This project helped US-based students, some of whom would otherwise be unable to attend GameSec 2013, to come and participate. We expect that many of them will build on their experience to produce more valuable research in this growing and important field.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/03/2014
Modified by: Matthew K Wright
